bibl.title: Letter from William Ludlow to the Adjutant General, October 27, 1900

div1.p: Ludlow defends his position against Wood's charges of concealing facts about yellow fever in Havana. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from William Ludlow to the Adjutant General, October 27, 1900
div1.opener:
1744 G Street, N.W.
WAR COLLEGE BOARD
Washington, D.C.
October 27, 1900
To the
Adjutant General, U.S.A.,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
As a matter of official record I enclose certain publica-
tions and correspondence, growing out of recent interviews with
General Wood by newspaper correspondents, viz: a clipping from the
New York Evening Post of October 23; my note of October 24 to
General Wood; an extended interview with him in the Evening Post of
October 24; his reply, dated October 25, to my note of the 24th,
which reached me October 26, subsequent to his departure from the
City; and my further letter to him of October 27;- there are also
two clippings from the Evening Post of October 26, covering brief
statements from General Brooke and me.

I am not concerned with explanations of the existing
epidemic of yellow fever in Havana, or elsewhere in Cuba, having no
responsibility in the Island and no more knowledge of current
events there than I may derive from newspapers, but I am concerned
with the refutation of any declaration or intimation of suppression
or perversion of any material fact pertaining to my former official
responsibility, and I desire to characterize as wholly false and
pernicious the imputation that the data as to yellow fever were in
any wise concealed or kept secret during my administration.

It was with the purpose of giving him the opportunity to
make public correction or the misstatements attributed to him that
my note to General Wood was made, and my expectation in the matter
would have been met by an explicit and frank denial to me and to
the press that he had either made such an accusation or believed it
to be true.

His reply, I regret to say, does not do this, and in draft-
ing it, as well as in his interview of the 24th,
he has overlooked certain facts that must be officially known
-2-
to him, and certainly should have been fully considered when
the ignoring of them leads to erroneous and misleading statements
reflecting injuriously upon other officers.

1. The utmost endeavor was made to enforce with penalties any
concealment of a suspicious case of infectious or contagious disease
of any kind. All such were to be immediately reported by telephone
or messenger to the Chief Sanitary Officer. All cases were im-
mediately investigated and due measures taken, by isolation or removal
of patient and thorough disinfection of premises and belongings.

2. A special yellow fever board was appointed of Army sur-
geons and civil physicians of high standing for the express purpose
of investigating and diagnosing cases and prescribing disposition.

3. Daily reports were made by the Chief Sanitary Officer to
my office and forwarded to General Brooke, giving all particulars
of cases, etc., and these data were open to public inspection and
use and at the disposal of the press in all three offices.

4. Every month a printed report of vital statistics, of the
form enclosed, was issued and widely distributed in the United
States as well as in the Island, giving accurate and authentic parti-
culars, and effecting full publicity as to all the data in question.

5. In addition, the annual reports gave the consolidated
statistics in full, with analyses and discussions.

It would be difficult to provide a more effective and gen-
eral means of distributing valid information in a matter of so much
public interest, and in fact publicity was neither avoidable nor
avoided.

The yellow fever had ceased to be a matter of serious con-
cern, either to ourselves or to our friends in the United States.
The command was free from it. Civil cases, due to the heavy non-
immune importations, were entirely under control, no case being per-
mitted to give rise to another, and the general conditions were
-3-
so far satisfactory as to be matter of congratulation instead of
apprehension. There was no “panic” of any kind, nor any “deluge
of anxious letters” from the United States or elsewhere.

There was and could be no objection to the publication
of this information, and official means were used to secure it.
It was refused to no one, and the newspaper correspondents could
have reported it every day had they thought it of sufficient inter-
est and importance to cable.

General Wood has the right to protect himself from hostile
criticism by any legitimate means at his disposal, but exceeds both
his rights as an individual, and his obligations due to his service,
in seeking to defend himself by impugning the administration of
others and furnishing the material for public misrepresentation.

As this matter has been given so much publicity, I desire
that this communication be laid before the Secretary of War and be
made of record in the War Department.
div1.closer:
Your obedient servant, William Ludlow. Brigadier General, U.S.A.
8 Enclosures.
